event.title: was believed to be the seat of the government of Datu Bendahara Kalantiaw III, the promulgator of the Code of Kalantiaw in 1433

data.event: Batan was believed to be the seat of the government of Datu Bendahara Kalantiaw III, the promulgator of the Code of Kalantiaw in 1433.

event.title: was established by the Augustinians in 1601

data.event: The parish in Batan was established by the Augustinians in 1601 under the patronage of Our Lady of Immaculate Conception.

event.title: was first incorporated to Aclan or Aklan (now

data.event: Batan was first incorporated to Aclan or Aklan (now Kalibo) in 1603 and in 1789 it became an independent municipality.
Batan was first incorporated to Aclan or Aklan (now Kalibo) in 1603 and in 1789 it became an independent municipality.
In 1903, Batan was again incorporated to the new town of New Washington and became independent again in 1931.
In 1903, Batan was again incorporated to the new town of New Washington and became independent again in 1931.

event.title: 1957, the Kalantiaw National Shrine marker was erected

data.event: In 1957, the Kalantiaw National Shrine marker was erected by the Philippine Historical and Cultural Society to honor the significance of Datu Kalantiaw where it displays a copy of the “original manuscript” of the Code.

event.title: years of investigation and historical findings, the National Historical Institute concluded

data.event: In 2004 however, after years of investigation and historical findings, the National Historical Institute concluded that the Code of Kalantiaw was fake and a hoax.
